skos.definition: Serum magnesium concentration below 1.8 mg/dL (0.75 mmol/L), commonly caused by GI losses, diuretics, or alcoholism, and critically important because it causes refractory hypokalemia and hypocalcemia.
skos.scopeNote: Often underdiagnosed; critical for potassium and calcium homeostasis

content.title: Hypomagnesemia
content.summary: Hypomagnesemia (Mg <1.8 mg/dL) is common, often underdiagnosed, and critically important because it causes refractory hypokalemia and hypocalcemia. Common causes include alcoholism, diuretics, GI losses, and medications (PPIs, aminoglycosides). Treatment requires both magnesium replacement and addressing the underlying cause.
key_points: Causes refractory hypokalemia - must correct Mg for K repletion to work
Causes refractory hypocalcemia - inhibits PTH secretion and action
Common causes: alcoholism, diuretics, diarrhea, PPIs, aminoglycosides
Clinical features similar to hypocalcemia: tremor, tetany, seizures, arrhythmias
ECG: prolonged QT, torsades de pointes, widened QRS
IV magnesium sulfate for severe/symptomatic; oral for mild/chronic
Serum Mg poorly reflects total body stores - can be low even with normal serum level
content.statement: Hypomagnesemia is one of the most clinically important electrolyte disorders because of its effects on potassium and calcium homeostasis. Any patient with refractory hypokalemia or hypocalcemia should have magnesium checked and repleted, as other electrolyte abnormalities will not correct until magnesium is normalized.

explanation.intuition: Magnesium is the 'behind-the-scenes' electrolyte that makes everything else work properly. It's required for the Na+/K+-ATPase pump (so cells can hold onto potassium) and for PTH secretion and action (so the body can maintain calcium). When magnesium is low, these systems fail, and no amount of potassium or calcium supplementation will work until magnesium is replaced.
explanation.key_insight: Think of magnesium as the 'master key' for other electrolytes. When you see hypokalemia that won't correct despite replacement, or hypocalcemia with 'normal' PTH that should be elevated, always check magnesium. Replacing it often 'unlocks' the ability to correct the other abnormalities.
explanation.technical_details: Magnesium is required for: (1) Na+/K+-ATPase activity - low Mg causes K+ to leak out of cells; (2) ROMK channel function - low Mg causes renal K+ wasting; (3) PTH secretion - severely low Mg inhibits PTH release; (4) PTH action - low Mg causes end-organ PTH resistance. Magnesium also stabilizes ion channels and is a cofactor for hundreds of enzymatic reactions.

definitions_glossary.ROMK_channel: Renal outer medullary potassium channel; magnesium required for proper function; causes renal K+ wasting when Mg low
definitions_glossary.sodium_potassium_ATPase: Na+/K+ pump; requires magnesium as cofactor; dysfunction causes intracellular K+ depletion
definitions_glossary.Gitelman_syndrome: Genetic disorder causing renal magnesium and potassium wasting; mimics thiazide diuretic effect
definitions_glossary.proton_pump_inhibitors: PPIs cause hypomagnesemia through decreased intestinal absorption; often severe and refractory
definitions_glossary.loop_diuretics: Increase renal magnesium excretion via thick ascending limb
definitions_glossary.thiazide_diuretics: Cause renal magnesium wasting in the distal tubule
definitions_glossary.alcoholism: Major cause of hypomagnesemia through poor intake, GI losses, and renal wasting
definitions_glossary.torsades_de_pointes: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with prolonged QT; IV magnesium is treatment of choice
definitions_glossary.aminoglycosides: Cause renal magnesium wasting; can persist weeks after drug discontinuation
definitions_glossary.refeeding_syndrome: Rapid electrolyte shifts when malnourished patients are fed; causes hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia
definitions_glossary.magnesium_sulfate: IV preparation for severe hypomagnesemia; 1-2 g over 15-60 minutes
definitions_glossary.magnesium_oxide: Oral preparation with poor absorption but high elemental Mg content
definitions_glossary.magnesium_citrate: Oral preparation with better absorption; can cause diarrhea
definitions_glossary.urinary_magnesium: Low (<2 mEq/day or FEMg <2%) indicates GI losses; high indicates renal wasting

pathophysiology.mechanism: Hypomagnesemia develops from decreased absorption, increased GI/renal losses, or redistribution. Effects on other electrolytes are due to magnesium's role in Na+/K+-ATPase function, ROMK channel activity, and PTH secretion/action.

decreased_intake: Total parenteral nutrition without Mg supplementation

laboratory: 24-hour urine magnesium or spot FEMg to differentiate renal vs GI losses

interpretation.FEMg_less_2_percent: Appropriate renal conservation → GI losses or redistribution
interpretation.FEMg_greater_4_percent: Renal magnesium wasting → diuretics, drugs, genetic disorders

options: Magnesium citrate (better absorbed but laxative effect)
mild_asymptomatic.note: GI side effects (diarrhea) may limit oral dosing

severe_symptomatic.dose: Magnesium sulfate 1-2 g IV over 15-60 minutes
severe_symptomatic.follow_with: Continuous infusion 4-8 g over 24 hours if ongoing losses
severe_symptomatic.monitoring: Check Mg levels every 6-12 hours; monitor for hypotension, bradycardia

torsades_de_pointes.treatment: Magnesium sulfate 2 g IV push over 1-2 minutes
torsades_de_pointes.note: First-line treatment even if Mg is normal

address_underlying_cause: Consider amiloride (K-sparing diuretic that reduces renal Mg loss)
Correct other electrolyte abnormalities (K, Ca) after Mg repleted
treatment_options.monitoring: Serum Mg, K, Ca levels; renal function; cardiac rhythm

prognosis.recovery: Excellent with appropriate replacement and treatment of cause
prognosis.complications: Cardiac arrhythmias including torsades can be fatal if untreated

learning_objectives: Recognize common causes of hypomagnesemia (alcoholism, diuretics, PPIs)
Explain why hypomagnesemia causes refractory hypokalemia and hypocalcemia
Differentiate renal from GI magnesium losses using urinary studies
Describe the clinical manifestations of hypomagnesemia
Outline treatment with IV vs oral magnesium replacement
Explain why magnesium is first-line treatment for torsades de pointes
clinical_pearls: PPIs are an underrecognized cause of severe hypomagnesemia
Serum Mg is a poor marker of total body stores - patients can be deficient with 'normal' levels
Magnesium is first-line for torsades de pointes even if serum Mg is normal
Oral magnesium causes diarrhea which can worsen magnesium losses - catch-22
Alcoholics often need weeks of replacement due to depleted total body stores

common_question_stems: Alcoholic with hypokalemia that won't correct with K replacement
Patient on PPI with muscle cramps and low Mg
Patient on thiazide with hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and low Mg
exam_tips: Can't correct K without correcting Mg first
Can't correct Ca without correcting Mg first
Low urinary Mg = GI loss; high urinary Mg = renal wasting

teaching_cases.scenario: 52-year-old alcoholic man with tremor and weakness. K+ 2.9, Mg 1.1, Ca 7.8. Multiple K+ replacements have not corrected the hypokalemia.
teaching_cases.key_findings: Refractory hypokalemia with concurrent hypomagnesemia and hypocalcemia
teaching_cases.diagnosis: Alcohol-related hypomagnesemia causing refractory hypokalemia and hypocalcemia
teaching_cases.management: IV magnesium sulfate first, then potassium and calcium replacement, alcohol cessation
